thread.title: Cardinals cruise to win over Sting
thread.title_full: Cardinals cruise to win over Sting

title: Cardinals cruise to win over Sting
text: Cardinals cruise to win over Sting Redwood Valley advances to Section 3AA semifinals with 39-15 rout of YME Comment Posted Oct. 15, 2015 at 9:12 AM Posted Oct. 15, 2015 at 9:12 AM Redwood Valley inched one game closer to its inevitable rematch with the Pipestone Area Arrows by dominating outmanned YME 39-15 Tuesday night in Section 3AA quarterfinal action held at Inglis Field. With the win the Cardinals (6-3) will now host St.James Area – a 31-20 upset winner over third-seeded Lakeview – in the Section 3AA semifinals at 1 p.m. Saturday afternoon in Redwood Falls. It was just the second win of the season for the Saints (2-7) who were steamrolled by the Cardinals 48-7 in week five. Top-seed Pipestone Area (9-0) crushed eighth-seed GFW 56-0 and will face Windom Area – who it defeated 42-0 in week three – in the other semifinal. In other words, mark your calendar for Friday, Oct. 23 at 7:30 p.m. in Marshall (SMSU), because Redwood Valley vs. Pipestone Area II will be the feature presentation on that night. The two teams hooked up Sept. 25 in Pipestone, with the Arrows surviving 26-18 in overtime. “We’re one game closer to our match-up with Pipestone Area which is what we’ve wanted all along,” Coach Matt Lundeen said. “We will not overlook St. James, but our kids are excited for this opportunity to make a deep run in the postseason.” Tuesday night the Cards took control early in the first half, as sophomore Logan Josephson exploded on a nice 55-yard touchdown run around the right end for a 7-0 lead. Just over two minutes later the Cards would score again, as sophomore Mitch Irlbeck connected with Cade Johnson on a beautiful fade to the right corner of the end zone that would up the lead to 14-0. The Sting (1-8) – who had come into the contest having been outscored 170-0 in their previous four outings – played scrappy for most of the first half, but the Cards would apply the dagger with two scores in the final 2:11 of the second quarter. Josephson scored his second touchdown of the night on a two-yard plunge, and with just six seconds to play, Johnson hit senior Collin Rasmussen on a 27-yard strike to make it 28-0 at the half. “It was nice to be able to punch in those two late scores to really take control,” Lundeen said. “Once we settled in we played well defensively and offensively I thought it was a good, efficient effort tonight.” Johnson – who has opened some eyes with his booming leg this fall – converted a 43-yard field goal to make it 31-0 in the third. The Cards would add a safety, and then Josephson would cap off a big night with his third touchdown, this time on a 42-yard scamper. He would finish with six carries for 113 yards and three touchdowns, averaging 18.7 yards per carry. Page 2 of 2 - Johnson would finish 7-of-12 passing for 113 yards and a score and had four rushes for 29 yards. Dan Kohler added eight carries for 53 yards, and freshman Josiah Hultquist had three late carries for 20 yards. Brady Goblirsh added one carry for 14 yards, Jared Lund had one carry for eight yards and Cain Bratsch had three carries for six yards. Irlbeck had three catches for 42 yards and was 1-of-1 passing for 22 yards and a score. Bailey Sommers had two catches for 42 yards, Rasmussen had one catch for 27 yards and a score, Johnson added one catch for 22 yards and a score and TommyAmberg added one catch for three yards. Defensively, the Cards were led by Kohler with eight tackles (five solo) and a fumble recovery. Connor O’Leary added eight tackles (five solo) a sack and 1 1/2 tackles-for-loss, and Josephson had eight tackles (three solo) and a tackle-for-loss. Tucker Machart had four tackles, a fumble recovery and an interception, Jared Lund added a fumble recovery and Travis Rebstock had a tackle-for-loss. Section 3AA Quarterfinals
